Metadata.Title: Require Authentication And Authorization for All Sensitive Pages
Metadata.DirectLink: Require Authentication And Authorization for All Sensitive Pages

Content.Data:
Applies to

  • Java

What to Do

Require authentication and authorization for all sensitive pages. Use role-based authorization policies.

Why

All pages that have private information should require authentication and authorization to prevent unauthorized information disclosure. Use role-based authorization policies because they are relatively simple to manage correctly.

How

To require authentication and authorization for all sensitive pages:

  1. Identify all sensitive pages. Make a list of all pages that handle sensitive or private information.

  2. Define roles. Define access roles for your application. These roles should include administrative users and various types of users specific to your application.

  3. Use JAAS to implement authentication and role-based access control. Implementing authentication and authorization with JAAS is an involved process that has a significant impact on the application architecture. Please, follow the links at the bottom of this page to find out more about using JAAS.

Additional Resources

  • For more information about JAAS, please see http://www.mooreds.com/jaas.html
  • For a JAAS authorization tutorial, please see http://download.oracle.com/javase/6/docs/technotes/guides/security/jaas/tutorials/GeneralAcnAndAzn.html
  • For a JAAS reference guide, please see http://download.oracle.com/javase/6/docs/technotes/guides/security/jaas/JAASRefGuide.html
  • For more information about JAAS, please see http://server.pramati.com/docstore/1270002/index.htm
  • For a description of JAAS features, please see http://www.javaworld.com/javaworld/jw-09-2002/jw-0913-jaas.html

Authorization Guidelines

  • Perform Role-based Security Checks
  • Require Authentication and Authorization for All Sensitive Pages
  • Make Authentication and Authorization Policies Configurable
  • Deny All Access by Default
  • Check Access Control Permissions When Referencing Objects
  • Use Indirect Object References
  • Partition the Application Between Public and Private Domains
  • Secure the Account Administration Functionality
  • Automatically Lock Inactive User Accounts
  • Consider Using JAAS for Authorization

Authorization Checklists

  • Role-based Security Checks Are Performed
  • Authentication and Authorization Are Required for All Sensitive Pages
  • Authentication and Authorization Policies Are Configurable
  • All Access Is Denied by Default
  • Access Control Permissions Are Checked When Referencing Objects
  • Indirect Object References Are Used
  • The Application Is Partitioned into Public and Private Domains
  • Account Administration Functionality Is Secured
  • Inactive User Accounts Are Automatically Locked
